author: Reuters In Paris
title: Explosion at Flamanville nuclear plant in western France | Environment | The Guardian
text:
Nuclear power Explosion at Flamanville nuclear plant in western France 
Government official says there is no nuclear risk but reports suggest five people may have been slightly injured in blast The Flamanville nuclear power plant. Photograph: Charly Triballeau/AFP/Getty Images View more sharing options Thursday 9 February 2017 11.17 GMT Last modified on Thursday 9 February 2017 11.20 GMT 
An explosion has occurred at EDF’s Flamanville nuclear plant in France but there is no nuclear risk, a local government official said. 
Ouest-France newspaper said there may be some injuries and M6 radio said five people had been slightly injured, but neither report could be independently verified. 
Officials at the state-backed company’s Paris headquarters had no immediate comment and officials at the plant in western France could not be reached. 
The Flamanville 1 and 2 reactors were built in the 1980s. A new reactor is being built at the site but the explosion did not take place there, a spokeswoman said. 
The nuclear safety authority ASN said it had no information and could not immediately comment. 
More details soon …
